title: Isaiah Chapter 26 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Isaiah chapter 26 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Isaiah Chapter 26 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Isaiah Chapter 26.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 26:1, what will God appoint for walls and bulwarks?
options: Salvation
Peace
Justice
Mercy
questions.correctAnswer: Salvation
questions.explanation: Isaiah 26:1 states that salvation will God appoint for walls and bulwarks.

questions.question: Who is allowed to enter the gates according to Isaiah 26:2?
options: The righteous nation which keepeth the truth
The poor and needy
The enemies of God
The children of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: The righteous nation which keepeth the truth
questions.explanation: Isaiah 26:2 commands to open the gates so that the righteous nation which keepeth the truth may enter in.

questions.question: What does God promise to keep in perfect peace according to Isaiah 26:3?
options: Whose mind is stayed on Him
The meek and humble
The poor and needy
The strong and mighty
questions.correctAnswer: Whose mind is stayed on Him
questions.explanation: Isaiah 26:3 says God will keep in perfect peace those whose mind is stayed on Him because they trust in Him.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 26:4, in whom should we trust forever?
options: The LORD JEHOVAH
The kings of the earth
The priests
Our own strength
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD JEHOVAH
questions.explanation: Isaiah 26:4 instructs to trust in the LORD JEHOVAH forever, for He is everlasting strength.

questions.question: What happens to the lofty city according to Isaiah 26:5?
options: He layeth it low even to the ground
It is exalted and protected
It becomes a place of refuge
It prospers and grows
questions.correctAnswer: He layeth it low even to the ground
questions.explanation: Isaiah 26:5 says God brings down the lofty city and lays it low even to the ground and dust.

questions.question: Who treads down the lofty city according to Isaiah 26:6?
options: The feet of the poor and the needy
The armies of the LORD
The kings of the earth
The angels of God
questions.correctAnswer: The feet of the poor and the needy
questions.explanation: Isaiah 26:6 states the foot shall tread down the lofty city, even the feet of the poor and the steps of the needy.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 26:7, what is the way of the just?
options: Uprightness
Riches
Power
Honor
questions.correctAnswer: Uprightness
questions.explanation: Isaiah 26:7 says the way of the just is uprightness, and God weighs the path of the just.

questions.question: What do the inhabitants of the world learn when God's judgments are in the earth according to Isaiah 26:9?
options: Righteousness
Fear
Power
Wealth
questions.correctAnswer: Righteousness
questions.explanation: Isaiah 26:9 explains that when God's judgments are in the earth, the inhabitants of the world will learn righteousness.

questions.question: True or False: According to Isaiah 26:10, the wicked will learn righteousness if favor is shown to them.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 26:10 states that even if favor is shown to the wicked, he will not learn righteousness.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 26:13, who alone will the people mention the name of?
options: God
Other lords
Kings of the earth
The prophets
questions.correctAnswer: God
questions.explanation: Isaiah 26:13 says they have been under other lords but by God alone will they make mention of His name.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 26:19 say will happen to the dead?
options: They shall live and arise
They shall remain in the dust
They shall be forgotten
They shall be judged immediately
questions.correctAnswer: They shall live and arise
questions.explanation: Isaiah 26:19 proclaims that the dead shall live, and together with the speaker's dead body shall arise.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Isaiah 26:20: 'Come, my people, enter thou into thy ______, and shut thy doors about thee.'
options: chambers
house
tent
city
questions.correctAnswer: chambers
questions.explanation: Isaiah 26:20 says to enter into thy chambers and shut thy doors about thee.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 26:16, when did the people pour out a prayer to the LORD?
options: When thy chastening was upon them
When they were prosperous
When they were joyful
When they were victorious
questions.correctAnswer: When thy chastening was upon them
questions.explanation: Isaiah 26:16 states that in trouble they poured out a prayer when God's chastening was upon them.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 26:14 says that the dead will rise again.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 26:14 clearly states that they are dead and shall not live; they are deceased and shall not rise.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 26:21 indicates that the LORD will punish the inhabitants of the earth for their iniquity.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 26:21 says the LORD cometh out of his place to punish the inhabitants of the earth for their iniquity.

medium.title: Isaiah Chapter 26 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Isaiah Chapter 26 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Isaiah 26, what biblical truth would you share about finding peace?
options: Perfect peace comes from trusting God and keeping our minds focused on Him.
Peace comes from avoiding difficult situations.
Peace is found by relying on our own strength.
Peace comes only after all problems are solved.
questions.correctAnswer: Perfect peace comes from trusting God and keeping our minds focused on Him.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 26:3 teaches that God keeps in perfect peace those whose minds are stayed on Him because they trust Him. Verses 4 and 8 also emphasize trusting the LORD and waiting for Him.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 26, how should believers respond when facing injustice or oppression in daily life?
options: Trust God who will humble the proud and bring justice.
Fight back with equal force to those who oppress.
Ignore injustice and focus on personal gain.
Seek revenge to prove strength.
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God who will humble the proud and bring justice.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 26:5-6 shows that God brings down the lofty city and humbles the proud, allowing even the poor to tread upon it, indicating His justice. Verse 7 highlights the upright way of the just being weighed by God.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged because their prayers seem unanswered. Based on Isaiah 26, what encouragement would you give about persistence in prayer?
options: Continue to seek God early and with your whole spirit, trusting His timing.
Stop praying if you don’t see immediate results.
Only pray when you feel like it.
Pray only for personal success.
questions.correctAnswer: Continue to seek God early and with your whole spirit, trusting His timing.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 26:9 encourages seeking God early and with the whole spirit, desiring His judgment and righteousness. Verse 8 also speaks of waiting for the LORD’s way and judgment.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 26 teach us about integrity in our daily walk?
options: The way of the just is uprightness, and God weighs their path.
Integrity is optional if no one is watching.
Being just means only following what feels right.
Integrity depends on the company you keep.
questions.correctAnswer: The way of the just is uprightness, and God weighs their path.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 26:7 states the way of the just is uprightness and God, who is most upright, weighs their path, emphasizing the importance of integrity.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 26 suggest about God’s strength and our trust in Him?
options: Trust in the LORD forever because He is everlasting strength.
Trust in human wisdom rather than God.
Strength comes from wealth and power.
God’s strength is limited and temporary.
questions.correctAnswer: Trust in the LORD forever because He is everlasting strength.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 26:4 clearly instructs to trust in the LORD forever, for He is everlasting strength, encouraging believers to rely on God’s power.

questions.question: When a believer faces hardship and chastening, what attitude does Isaiah 26 recommend?
options: Pour out prayer and seek God earnestly during trouble.
Complain and question God’s love.
Ignore God and rely only on yourself.
Avoid fellowship with others.
questions.correctAnswer: Pour out prayer and seek God earnestly during trouble.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 26:16 describes how people visit the LORD in trouble and pour out prayers when chastening is upon them, showing the proper response to trials.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 26 describe the nation’s growth and God’s glory in practical Christian living?
options: God increases the nation and is glorified as His people spread afar.
Growth depends solely on human effort.
The nation grows by ignoring God.
God’s glory is unrelated to nation’s increase.
questions.correctAnswer: God increases the nation and is glorified as His people spread afar.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 26:15 speaks of God increasing the nation and being glorified as His people are removed to the ends of the earth, illustrating God’s providence in blessing and expansion.

questions.question: True or False: According to Isaiah 26, even if favor is shown to the wicked, they will not learn righteousness.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 26:10 states that even if favor is shown to the wicked, they will not learn righteousness but will do unjustly.

questions.question: How should believers respond to God’s judgment and indignation according to Isaiah 26?
options: Hide in their chambers and trust God until indignation passes.
Provoke God to mercy by rebellion.
Ignore the warning and continue sinning.
Try to negotiate with God.
questions.correctAnswer: Hide in their chambers and trust God until indignation passes.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 26:20 advises God’s people to enter their chambers, shut doors, and hide for a little moment until the indignation passes, showing trust and patience during judgment.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 26 teach about resurrection and hope for believers?
options: The dead shall live again and arise, and the earth will cast out the dead.
Death is final with no hope of resurrection.
Only a few will be resurrected.
Resurrection depends on human works.
questions.correctAnswer: The dead shall live again and arise, and the earth will cast out the dead.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 26:19 clearly states that the dead shall live and arise, and the earth will cast out the dead, offering hope of resurrection.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with envy towards others. Based on Isaiah 26, what warning would you share?
options: Envy leads to shame and destruction by God’s fire on enemies.
Envy is harmless if kept private.
Envy is a sign of faith.
Envy should be ignored as it is natural.
questions.correctAnswer: Envy leads to shame and destruction by God’s fire on enemies.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 26:11 warns that those who envy God’s people will see and be ashamed, and the fire of the LORD’s enemies will devour them.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 26 emphasize the importance of remembering and mentioning only the true God in worship?
options: Only by God will we make mention of His name, rejecting other lords.
We can worship any lord as long as it feels right.
Mentioning many gods gives more blessings.
Worship is not important in daily life.
questions.correctAnswer: Only by God will we make mention of His name, rejecting other lords.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 26:13 states that though other lords have had dominion, only the LORD’s name will be mentioned, highlighting exclusive worship.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 26 teaches that God is actively involved in the work and peace of His people.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 26:12 affirms that the LORD ordains peace and that He has wrought all works in His people.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 26 illustrate the experience of God's people during times of trial?
options: Like a woman in labor, experiencing pain but expecting deliverance.
Like a carefree child without worries.
Like a warrior winning every battle easily.
Like one who ignores pain and refuses help.
questions.correctAnswer: Like a woman in labor, experiencing pain but expecting deliverance.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 26:17 compares the people’s suffering to a woman in labor pains nearing delivery, symbolizing intense struggle with hope for relief.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Isaiah 26:2 says, 'Open ye the gates, that the ______ nation which keepeth the truth may enter in.'
options: righteous
wicked
proud
powerful
questions.correctAnswer: righteous
questions.explanation: Isaiah 26:2 calls for gates to be opened for the righteous nation that keeps the truth, emphasizing holiness and obedience.

hard.title: Isaiah Chapter 26 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Isaiah Chapter 26.

questions.question: What is the metaphor used in Isaiah 26:1 to describe the security and salvation God provides to Judah?
options: A strong city with walls and bulwarks
A flourishing garden with abundant fruit
A mighty river that never runs dry
A fortress surrounded by fire
questions.correctAnswer: A strong city with walls and bulwarks
questions.explanation: Isaiah 26:1 explicitly uses the metaphor of a 'strong city' and 'walls and bulwarks' to symbolize God's appointed salvation and protection.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 26:3, what is the condition for receiving perfect peace from God?
options: Whose mind is stayed on God because he trusteth in Him
Who fasts and prays regularly
Who sacrifices offerings in the temple
Who follows the laws of the kings
questions.correctAnswer: Whose mind is stayed on God because he trusteth in Him
questions.explanation: Isaiah 26:3 states that perfect peace is kept for the one whose mind is fixed on God and who trusts in Him, highlighting trust as the key condition.

questions.question: Isaiah 26:4 emphasizes trusting in the LORD because He is what?
options: Everlasting strength
A merciful healer
A righteous judge
A wise counselor
questions.correctAnswer: Everlasting strength
questions.explanation: The verse clearly states that the LORD JEHOVAH is everlasting strength, encouraging perpetual trust in Him.

questions.question: In Isaiah 26:5-6, what happens to the 'lofty city' and who treads it down?
options: It is laid low to the ground and trampled by the feet of the poor and needy
It is surrounded by fire and destroyed by the king's army
It is flooded and washed away by a mighty river
It is hidden by darkness and avoided by travelers
questions.correctAnswer: It is laid low to the ground and trampled by the feet of the poor and needy
questions.explanation: These verses describe the humbling of the proud city and how even the humble and needy will trample it down, indicating a reversal of fortunes.

questions.question: What literary device is prominently used in Isaiah 26:7 when describing the way of the just as uprightness and God weighing their path?
options: Parallelism
Chiasmus
Metaphor
Hyperbole
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: Isaiah 26:7 employs parallelism, a common Hebrew poetic device, by pairing 'the way of the just is uprightness' with 'thou dost weigh the path of the just' emphasizing God's righteousness and justice.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 26:9 express the psalmist's longing for God and relate it to a broader eschatological hope?
options: Desiring God at night and seeking Him early so that inhabitants learn righteousness through His judgments
Calling upon God only in times of war to defeat enemies
Fasting and offering sacrifices to appease God
Building altars on high places to honor God
questions.correctAnswer: Desiring God at night and seeking Him early so that inhabitants learn righteousness through His judgments
questions.explanation: The verse uses intense personal longing ('with my soul', 'with my spirit') and connects it to the universal hope that God's judgments will teach righteousness to all the earth.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 26:10, what is the response of the wicked when shown favor?
options: They do not learn righteousness and deal unjustly
They repent and turn to God
They build altars and offer sacrifices
They praise the majesty of the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: They do not learn righteousness and deal unjustly
questions.explanation: The verse highlights the stubbornness of the wicked who, even when shown favor, refuse to learn righteousness and continue in injustice.

questions.question: Which theme in Isaiah 26:12-13 reflects the historical context of foreign domination over Israel?
options: Acknowledgment that other lords had dominion but only God is to be worshipped
Celebration of military victories over all enemies
Call for Israel to establish a monarchy
Instruction to build a new temple
questions.correctAnswer: Acknowledgment that other lords had dominion but only God is to be worshipped
questions.explanation: These verses recognize that Israel had been under foreign domination ('other lords') but affirm exclusive worship and mention of the LORD alone, reflecting the historical subjugation and hope for restoration.

questions.question: What typological foreshadowing can be found in Isaiah 26:19 regarding the dead rising?
options: A prophecy of resurrection and eternal life
A metaphor for crop renewal after drought
A description of ancestral spirits returning
An allegory for political revival of Judah
questions.correctAnswer: A prophecy of resurrection and eternal life
questions.explanation: The verse speaks of the dead arising and singing, which is often interpreted as a prophetic foreshadowing of resurrection, a theme developed in later biblical texts like Daniel 12 and the New Testament.

questions.question: In Isaiah 26:20-21, what is the reason given for the people to hide in their chambers and shut their doors?
options: Until the indignation of the LORD is overpast
To prepare for a festival of thanksgiving
To avoid a foreign invasion
To mourn the death of kings
questions.correctAnswer: Until the indignation of the LORD is overpast
questions.explanation: The passage advises the people to conceal themselves temporarily until God's indignation or wrath has passed, indicating a time of judgment upon the earth.

questions.question: Which other biblical book contains a passage that most directly parallels the theme of resurrection found in Isaiah 26:19?
options: Daniel 12
Genesis 1
Exodus 20
Psalms 23
questions.correctAnswer: Daniel 12
questions.explanation: Daniel 12:2 discusses the resurrection of the dead, which closely parallels Isaiah 26:19's prophecy about the dead arising, linking both eschatological visions.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 26:14 declares that the dead will rise again and live forever.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 26:14 states that the dead are deceased and shall not live or rise, which contrasts with the resurrection theme in verse 19, highlighting different contexts or groups being referenced.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'Thy dew is as the dew of herbs' in Isaiah 26:19 in the ancient Near Eastern context?
options: It symbolizes life-giving moisture that enables resurrection and renewal
It refers to agricultural ritual offerings to gods
It is a metaphor for the abundance of royal blessings
It describes the morning prayers of the priests
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes life-giving moisture that enables resurrection and renewal
questions.explanation: In the ancient Near East, dew was understood as essential moisture for vegetation; here, it symbolizes God's revitalizing power that causes the dead to rise, connecting natural imagery with divine restoration.

questions.question: How does the description of the people in Isaiah 26:17-18 use childbirth imagery to express their spiritual condition?
options: They are in pain and travail but have brought forth wind, indicating unfulfilled hopes
They rejoice like a woman giving birth to a child
They are protected as a mother shields her infant
They are silent like a woman before labor
questions.correctAnswer: They are in pain and travail but have brought forth wind, indicating unfulfilled hopes
questions.explanation: The verses use the metaphor of a woman in labor who brings forth wind instead of a child to illustrate the people's suffering and lack of deliverance despite their spiritual travail.

questions.question: Which Hebrew poetic structure might be inferred from the paired concepts in Isaiah 26:8-9 regarding waiting and desiring the LORD?
options: Synonymous parallelism
Antithetic parallelism
Chiasm
Acrostic
questions.correctAnswer: Synonymous parallelism
questions.explanation: Verses 8-9 show synonymous parallelism, repeating similar ideas of waiting and desiring the LORD in different phrases to emphasize devotion and hope.

theological.title: Isaiah Chapter 26 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Isaiah Chapter 26 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 26:3, what is the condition for having perfect peace?
options: Whose mind is stayed on God and trusts in Him
Who performs many good works
Who fasts and prays continually
Who abides in the temple
questions.correctAnswer: Whose mind is stayed on God and trusts in Him
questions.explanation: Isaiah 26:3 teaches that perfect peace is granted to the one whose mind is steadfast on God and who trusts in Him. This corresponds with Philippians 4:7 where peace surpasses understanding is given through trusting God, and John 14:27 where Jesus promises peace to those who believe in Him.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 26:4 identify as the everlasting strength?
options: The LORD JEHOVAH
The temple of Jerusalem
The wisdom of the elders
The armies of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD JEHOVAH
questions.explanation: Isaiah 26:4 declares that the LORD JEHOVAH is everlasting strength, emphasizing God's eternal power and reliability. Psalm 46:1 and Deuteronomy 33:27 similarly affirm God's role as an eternal refuge and strength.

questions.question: In Isaiah 26:5-6, what happens to the lofty city and its inhabitants?
options: It is brought low to the dust and trodden down by the feet of the poor
It is exalted above all other cities
It is protected by God's angels
It becomes a place of refuge for the righteous
questions.correctAnswer: It is brought low to the dust and trodden down by the feet of the poor
questions.explanation: Verses 5 and 6 describe God's judgment on the proud city, bringing it low and allowing even the feet of the poor to tread upon it. This theme parallels Proverbs 16:18 and Luke 1:52 where God humbles the proud and lifts the lowly.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 26:7 say about the way of the just?
options: The way of the just is uprightness, and God weighs their path
The way of the just is hidden and mysterious
The way of the just is full of trials and suffering
The way of the just leads only to earthly prosperity
questions.correctAnswer: The way of the just is uprightness, and God weighs their path
questions.explanation: Isaiah 26:7 affirms that the just live uprightly and that God carefully weighs and judges their path, indicating divine justice and moral integrity. This resonates with Psalm 1:6 and Proverbs 21:2 where God examines the hearts and paths of the righteous.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 26:9, why will the inhabitants of the world learn righteousness when God's judgments are in the earth?
options: Because God's righteous judgments serve as a revelation and correction
Because they will fear human kings
Because they will be blinded by prosperity
Because they will follow the traditions of men
questions.correctAnswer: Because God's righteous judgments serve as a revelation and correction
questions.explanation: Isaiah 26:9 states that when God's judgments are executed on earth, people will learn righteousness, showing that divine discipline leads to moral awakening. This is consistent with Romans 1:18-20 and Hebrews 12:11 where God's judgment reveals truth and produces righteousness.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 26:10 say about the wicked even when favor is shown to them?
options: They do not learn righteousness and continue to act unjustly
They repent quickly and turn to God
They become leaders of the righteous
They receive blessings and peace
questions.correctAnswer: They do not learn righteousness and continue to act unjustly
questions.explanation: Verse 10 reveals that the wicked, despite receiving favor, fail to learn righteousness and persist in injustice. This aligns with Jeremiah 7:26 and Romans 1:21 where mercy is met with continued rebellion.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 26:11 describe the fate of God's enemies?
options: They shall see God's power and be ashamed, and the fire will devour them
They will succeed in overthrowing the righteous
They shall be forgiven unconditionally
They will be exalted above God's people
questions.correctAnswer: They shall see God's power and be ashamed, and the fire will devour them
questions.explanation: This verse speaks of God's enemies witnessing His power and being ashamed, with their destruction by fire symbolizing divine judgment. Similar themes appear in Nahum 1:6 and Revelation 20:9.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 26:12 say about the origin of the people's works?
options: God wrought all their works in them
They accomplished their works by their own strength
Their works were approved by kings
Their works were hidden from God
questions.correctAnswer: God wrought all their works in them
questions.explanation: Isaiah 26:12 attributes the people's works to God's sovereign activity within them, emphasizing divine providence. This matches with Philippians 2:13 and Ephesians 2:10, highlighting God's enabling power in believers.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 26:14, what is said about the dead who had dominion over God's people?
options: They are dead and shall not live again; their memory is destroyed
They shall rise and rule again
They have eternal life in the afterlife
They continue to influence the living
questions.correctAnswer: They are dead and shall not live again; their memory is destroyed
questions.explanation: This verse declares the finality of death for false rulers, with no resurrection or remembrance, reflecting God's judgment. This contrasts with the resurrection hope in Daniel 12:2 and John 5:28-29, showing judgment on the wicked.

questions.question: What metaphor does Isaiah 26:17 use to describe the people's suffering before deliverance?
options: A woman with child in labor pains
A tree bending in the storm
A soldier in battle
A traveler lost in the desert
questions.correctAnswer: A woman with child in labor pains
questions.explanation: Isaiah 26:17 compares the people's anguish to a woman in labor, illustrating intense suffering preceding new life or deliverance, similar to John 16:21 and Romans 8:22-23.

questions.question: What hope is expressed in Isaiah 26:19 regarding the dead?
options: The dead shall live and arise, and the earth will cast out the dead
The dead shall remain in the dust forever
The dead shall be forgotten and silent
The dead shall be consumed by fire
questions.correctAnswer: The dead shall live and arise, and the earth will cast out the dead
questions.explanation: This verse proclaims resurrection hope, promising life to the dead, aligning with resurrection teachings in Ezekiel 37:12-14 and 1 Corinthians 15:52-54.

questions.question: In Isaiah 26:20, what instruction is given to God's people during the time of indignation?
options: Enter your chambers and shut your doors to hide until the indignation passes
Go out boldly to confront the enemy
Build new cities and fortifications
Offer sacrifices to appease God
questions.correctAnswer: Enter your chambers and shut your doors to hide until the indignation passes
questions.explanation: The verse instructs God's people to seek protection and remain hidden during God's wrath, paralleling Revelation 6:15-17 and Ezekiel 38:14-23 where God's people are sheltered.

questions.question: What reason does Isaiah 26:21 give for the LORD coming out of His place?
options: To punish the inhabitants of the earth for their iniquity
To bless the nations with peace
To establish a new covenant with Israel
To build a temple on earth
questions.correctAnswer: To punish the inhabitants of the earth for their iniquity
questions.explanation: Isaiah 26:21 explains that God's coming out of His place is for judgment on sin, consistent with themes in Psalm 96:13 and Revelation 19:11-21 regarding divine justice.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 26:13, how does the people acknowledge God's sovereignty?
options: They mention only God's name, acknowledging no other lords
They worship many gods alongside the LORD
They rely on human leaders for guidance
They ignore God's name in their prayers
questions.correctAnswer: They mention only God's name, acknowledging no other lords
questions.explanation: Verse 13 denotes exclusive devotion to God by mentioning only His name, rejecting other lords, reflecting monotheistic faith as in Deuteronomy 6:4 and Isaiah 45:5.

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'strong city' mentioned in Isaiah 26:1?
options: It symbolizes God's appointed salvation and protection
It is a physical city built by human hands
It represents the enemies of Judah
It refers to a future earthly kingdom
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes God's appointed salvation and protection
questions.explanation: The 'strong city' in Isaiah 26:1 is a metaphor for God's salvation and protective power, matching imagery in Psalm 46:7 and Proverbs 18:10 where God is described as a refuge and fortress.
